title: 114_s2544
content: The Act titled "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" includes amendments related to anti-straw purchasing and firearms trafficking. The Act "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" introduces amendments to Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, including a new section on straw purchasing of firearms. It defines terms like "crime of violence" and "drug trafficking crime" for the purpose of this section. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" introduces new regulations regarding the purchase of firearms, including defining terms like "Federal crime of terrorism" and expanding on what constitutes a violation of purchasing firearms in interstate or foreign commerce. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" prohibits the purchase of firearms in interstate or foreign commerce from unlicensed individuals if there is reason to believe the buyer is involved in criminal activities or substance abuse. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" prohibits certain individuals from purchasing firearms, including those who have been adjudicated as mentally defective, committed to a mental institution, illegal aliens, dishonorably discharged from the Armed Forces, renounced their citizenship, or admitted to the US under a nonimmigrant visa. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" prohibits individuals who have renounced their citizenship from purchasing firearms if they are subject to a court order restraining them from harassing, stalking, or threatening an intimate partner or child, and if the court order includes a finding that they represent a credible threat. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" prohibits individuals convicted of misdemeanor domestic violence, non-residents, and non-citizens from selling firearms to prohibited persons. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" imposes penalties, including fines and imprisonment up to 15 years, for individuals who violate the law by using firearms in Federal crimes of terrorism, crimes of violence, or drug trafficking crimes. If a firearm is knowingly used in a crime of violence, the offender will face a longer sentence. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" imposes penalties for using firearms in Federal crimes of violence, with a maximum imprisonment of 25 years. Exceptions include lawful purchase for gifts, raffles, gratuities, bonuses, and awards. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" prohibits the trafficking of firearms across state lines if the sender knows or has reason to believe the recipient is prohibited from possessing a firearm. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2016" prohibits receiving firearms across state lines if the recipient knows it violates federal or state law, with penalties of up to 15 years imprisonment. Convicted individuals must forfeit any proceeds derived from the violation. The court shall order forfeiture of any proceeds obtained as a result of the violation and any property used to commit or facilitate the offense. Defendants who profit from violating section 932 or 933 may face fines. Defendants who profit from violating section 932 or 933 may face fines not exceeding twice the gross profits of the offense. Amendments to various sections of the United States Code expand the scope of offenses related to firearms trafficking and straw purchasing. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend its guidelines to increase penalties for offenses related to firearms trafficking and straw purchasing under sections 932 or 933 of title 18, United States Code. This includes ensuring that straw purchasers without significant criminal histories receive deterrent sentences. The Commission will review and amend guidelines to impose higher penalties on individuals affiliated with criminal enterprises under sections 932 or 933 of title 18, United States Code. Additionally, a technical amendment will be made to the table of sections for chapter 44 of title 18. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 922(D). This section addresses straw purchasing of firearms, trafficking in firearms, and includes provisions for forfeiture and fines. Section 922(d) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include new provisions regarding the sale or disposal of firearms and ammunition to individuals described in specific paragraphs, as well as intentions related to federal crimes of terrorism, violence, drug trafficking, or illegal exportation. The amendment to Section 922(d) of title 18, United States Code prohibits the sale or export of firearms or ammunition in violation of the law, except to licensed individuals or those granted relief from disabilities under specific conditions. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(A) include fines and imprisonment for knowingly violating subsections (d) or (g) of section 922. SEC. 5. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(D) involve expanding the scope of offenses under section 924, including sections 932 or 933. SEC. 6. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(H) are not specified in the provided text. SEC. 6. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(H) involve penalties for knowingly receiving or transferring firearms or ammunition for use in Federal crimes of terrorism, violence, drug trafficking, or other specified crimes, with fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(K) Amendment to Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, includes penalties for smuggling firearms or ammunition into or out of the United States with intent to engage in criminal activities, punishable under various laws. Penalties include fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. The amendment to Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, imposes penalties for smuggling firearms or ammunition with intent for criminal activities, punishable under specific laws. Offenses could result in fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. SEC. 8 prohibits the transfer of firearms to individuals believed to be agents of drug cartels unless continuously monitored. SEC. 9 clarifies that the Act does not establish a federal system of firearm registration.
